title.narrative: Strengthening National And Regional Development Planning: A Spatial Development Framework For Guinea-Bissau And A Regional Strategic And Spatial Development Plan For The Archipelago Of Bijagós (Bijagós 2030)

description.narrative:
Guinea-Bissau currently faces a complex scenario concerning population dynamics, which includes rapid and unbalanced urbanisation and rural-urban migration. Whilst in 1997 only 22,5% of the population lived in urban areas, in 2015 this number reached 42,16% (INE, 2015). At the same time, the capital (Bissau) already accounts for more than 25% of the national population, increasingly concentrating population growth. Significant growth is also seen, apart from the capital city, in other cities of the country, such as Bubaque, Gabú and Bafatá.
Settlements around the country lack functional services and infrastructure to accommodate existing and new demand. Population tend to concentrate in bigger cities to find better services and infrastructure. Nonetheless, those living in other regional centres and in the countryside face issues in access to facilities such as banking and transportation services, education and health facilities, among others and often travel to the Capital to address their needs. Moreover, certain regions of the country obtain more investments from development partners over others, where even duplicity of interventions frequently occur, while other regions are marked by the total absence of investments. This scenario is in part due to the lack of planning tools in place and due to the lack of coordination of interventions from multiple institutions.
To face these issues, there is a need for a more equitable spatial development in Guinea-Bissau to take place, involving data and mapping systems that can support a results-based management approach and development strategies based on objective and scientifically accepted criteria which are generated in a consensual manner, without leaving anyone and anywhere behind. Therefore, governments at both national and local levels, along with partners, must strategically invest in infrastructure and services based on an integrated spatial development framework, which takes into consideration current and future demographics and territorial issues.
In the national Strategic Plan, Terra Ranka, the country has identified nine hubs as important economic centres that should be enhanced to promote dynamic economic activities, being the Archipelago of Bijagós one of them. In the axis of Infrastructure and Urban Development, highlighted in Terra Ranka, the country developed 4 fields of action, including ‘land planning and urban development’. In this field, the immediate goal is to “renovate and build the principal urban centres in such a way as to endow them with infrastructure and functional systems and set them up as business hubs”. In this framework, the development of the Bolama-Bijagós archipelago is also a priority.
The archipelago entails an exceptional natural site of 88 islands and islets recognized as a UNESCO Biosphere reserve due to its natural environment wealth and cultural assets. The development of ecotourism in the region also entails a national priority, with the designation of the archipelago as a Special Tourism Zone, along with the preservation of biodiversity and the need to develop infrastructure.
Nevertheless, to achieve its potential, Bijagós requires support in developing strategic development plans that provide planning and design proposals, introducing innovative sustainable planning models and a tested set of tools principles adapted to the local context, to ensure the sustainable development of the region. These plans should be solidly built on a strong participatory approach and in the spatialization of current development challenges and opportunities.
